text.headline: Trilobite
text.text: Trilobites are an extinct arthropod that were extremely successful throughout the Paleozoic. Trilobites are named after the three longitudinal lobes (tri-lobe) that characterize their body plan. Like many arthropods, trilobites moulted regularly by breaking upen it's exoskeleton in the head region. Most trilobite fossils are therefore only the moulted tail, which stays whole throughout the moulting process.

text.headline: Graptolites
text.text: Graptolites are a delicate collonial fossil where tiny zooids live on stick-like or hair pin-like structure. This whole colony could often float across the ocean, allowing wide dispersal.

text.headline: Brachiopods
text.text: Brachiopods were hugely successful in the Ordovician, and are thus an important and common fossil in southern Ontario. Unlike pelecypods, brachiopods have two shells with different sizes and are thus somewhat assymmetrical when viewed from the side, and they also tend to be less fragile than many pelecypod fossils.

text.headline: Gastropods
text.text: Gastropods are a mollusc with a single shell like a snail. Paleozoic marine gastropods were fairly similar to modern gastropods and are easily recognizable by their spiral or conical shell patterns.

text.headline: Vertebrates
text.text: Paleozoic seaways were filled with fish by the late Silurian to Devonian. In fact the Devonian is known as 'the age of fish' for the incredible diversity of fish body plans that emerged during this period. Most fish are too delicate to fossilize under ordinary circumstances, and the most common fish fossils found are placoderm plates, which are a rigid armour-like covering on some Devonian fish, and teeth.

text.headline: Crinoids
text.text: Crinoids, or 'sea lillies' are a type of echinoderm which is a diverse phylum that includes starfish and sea urchins. Crinoids are delicate organisms with a long stem and arms made out of thousands of circular plates stacked upon each other. Crinoid stems often disarticulate (break up) into isolated cheerio-like plates, sometimes with a star-shaped hold caused by the pentaradial symmetry for which echinoderms are known.

text.headline: Rugose Corals
text.text: Rugose corals are often referred to as 'horn corals' because of their curved conical shape. They are easily recognized by the radiating septa visible when looking at the open end of the coral. Each 'horn' would have only held a single polyp, but it was not unusual for many of these corals to grow in close proximity to each other.

text.headline: Tabulate Corals
text.text: Tabulate corals are a common reef-building fossil in Ontario, and is characterised by it's honeycomb-like appearance. Each hexagonal hole would have held a single polyp (similar to an upside-down jellyfish) so that thousands of polyps would live together in a single colonial structure that grows upwards over time.

text.headline: Stromatolites
text.text: Stromatolites are finely-layered dome-like structures made by the slow growth of microbes on the seafloor. These are very unusual in Paleozoic rocks, but can be found in the Proterozoic strata of the Southern Province.

text.headline: Cephalapods
text.text: Unlike the soft squids and octopuses of today, many cephalopods in the Paleozoic had hard heavy shells. These shells could be up to a meter in length

text.headline: Bryozoans
text.text: Bryozoans are colloquially known as 'moss animals' for their soft branching appearance in living specimens. They are a highly collonial animal where thousands of individual 'zooids' live in tiny pores visible on delicate stick-like, fan-like, or mound-like structures.

text.headline: Trace Fossils
text.text: Instead of preserving the body of an organism, trace fossils record the 'traces' of biological activity like crawling, eating, or digging. The most common trace fossils are burrows formed by worms and other organisms living in the substrate.

text.headline: Tentaculites
text.text: A small cone shaped organism of mysterious origins. It may be related to gastropods, cephalopods, brachiopods, or even worms. Tentaculites can only be found in Ordovician and Devonian rocks after which it appears to have gone extinct. Some species lived on the seafloor while others appeared to aimlesssly drift in the oceans like plankton.
